intro: Oxydectes organensis, commonly known as the Organ Mountains dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its basal rosette of spoon-shaped leaves and yellow composite flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, with a deep root system that allows it to survive in dry conditions. Its flowers are composed of both ray and disk florets, typical of the Asteraceae family. Oxydectes organensis plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for various herbivores.
